docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, the drug safety gadfly, flew down the stairs of his headquarters here and swept out the door. ''I am so angry with the F.D.A.,'' he said. ''Let's go get a cup of coffee because I've talked myself hoarse.''

headline.main: Drug Industry's Longtime Critic Says 'I Told You So'

docs.abstract: Dr Sidney M Wolfe, director of Public Citizen, consumer advocacy group, describes his personal fight to make health care industry accountable and drugs and health products safe for consumer; founded organization over 30 years ago with Ralph Nader, who comments on working with Wolfe; several of Wolfe's crusades discussed; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, the drug safety gadfly, is on something of a roll.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gum disease has long been suspected of playing a role in heart disease and stroke. Now, a new study appears to make the relationship much more solid. Writing in the journal Circulation, researchers report that people with gum disease are more likely to have changes in the carotid artery -- a sign of atherosclerosis.

headline.main: Flossing: A String to the Heart

docs.abstract: Dr Moise Desvarieux of Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health leads study that supports link between gum disease and increased risk of heart disease; study, which is published in journal Circulation, finds that people with highest levels of four bacteria in gum disease also had thickest carotid arteries; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study appears to make the relationship between gum disease and heart disease and stroke much more solid.

docs.lead_paragraph: Are healthy people happier than seriously ill ones? Not necessarily.

headline.main: Health and Happiness Aren't Always Linked

docs.abstract: Dr Jason Riis of Princeton University leads study that shows patient happiness and health are not necessarily linked; research, which is published in Journal of Experimental Psychology, looked at attitudes of people with end-stage illness compared to control group of healthy volunteers; both groups registered about the same levels of happiness (M)
docs.snippet: Are healthy people happier than seriously ill ones? Not necessarily.

docs.lead_paragraph: Girls who are growing too slowly are referred to specialists half as often as boys, researchers say. The difference may be understandable, since boys tend to suffer greater social consequences if they are short. But the failure of doctors to send girls small for their age for closer examination can mean that serious problems are overlooked.
docs.abstract: Dr Adda Grimberg of Children's Hospital of Philadelphia leads study that shows girls who are growing at slower than normal rate are referred to specialists half as often as boys with growth problems; research is published in Journal of Pediatrics; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Girls who are growing too slowly are referred to specialists half as often as boys, researchers say.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM: Drinking alcohol with a meal prevents food poisoning. THE FACTS: Recent studies have found that a little alcohol may help ward off heart disease and slow dementia. But an old wives' tale suggests another reason to indulge in a drink or two with dinner: preventing food poisoning. Research over the years appears to confirm this. In 2002, for example, health officials in Spain studied an outbreak of salmonella among people who had been exposed to contaminated potato salad and tuna at a large banquet.
docs.abstract: Research finds that drinking alcohol with meal can reduce likelihood of food poisoning; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Research seems to confirm the old wives' tale that drinking with food prevents food poisoning.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a classic public health problem: how much information is enough to warn the public about a potential health threat? In deciding, health officials must weigh the risks of losing credibility by causing unnecessary alarm against the benefits of releasing timely information to prevent one or a few cases from turning into an outbreak.

headline.main: A Public Health Quandary: When Should the Public Be Told?

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas R Frieden, New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene commissioner, warns public about discovery of one case of drug-resistant HIV infection, which rapidly progressed to full-blown AIDS; infected man had large number of sexual partners over short period of time; critics say Frieden did not have enough evidence of public health concern to go forward with announcement, but others acknowledge that there are benefits in notifying public about potential outbreak and hazards; specific case discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors and public health officials must weigh the benefits of knowledge against the risk of alarm.
